pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>isolation streak plate</button> technique is a crucial procedure for the microbiology laboratory that enables the generation of <button class='glossary-text'>pure cultures</button>. From a mixture of microorganisms, the student will inoculate an agar plate using this technique, thereby producing isolated colonies.

pageData.text: A microbiome is a group of different microorganisms, including bacteria, fungi, and protists, that form a community in a particular area. Microbiomes exist all over including on and within other larger organisms. For instance, one microbiome that has received a lot of attention is within the human digestive tract, sometimes referred to as THE microbiome. However, microbiomes also exist on human skin, within the digestive tracts of most animals, in plant roots, and in soil. And, importantly, each of these microbial communities is unique and plays a particular role in its location. The human gut microbiome, for example, varies from person to person and this uniqueness has been linked to various metabolic disorders and can even affect mental health. To study one of these unique groups, it is important to be able to isolate individual strains to be grown and characterized, often with molecular sequencing.  The streak plate isolation technique is an important tool in isolating individual species from within a whole microbiome to compare between or within species. Though it is not useful for all microbes, especially anaerobes, streak plate isolation allows scientists to better compare the microbial makeups of these unique communities.

pageData.text: When microbiologists study microbes, they often work with . A pure culture is one in which the microbes are genetically identical to one another and free from other species or strains. However, when samples are taken from the environment or from a patient, they almost always contain a variety of bacteria, fungi, and other microbes and must be considered a . To obtain pure cultures from a mixed culture, microbiologists must first isolate the different microorganisms from one another.

The <button class='glossary-text'>isolation streak plate</button> is a common approach used to produce pure cultures from a mixed sample. The goal of this technique is to spread individual microorganisms so far apart on the surface of a solid medium that they do not touch one another. When each microbial cell divides, it gives rise to genetically identical progeny. With each generation of cell division, the number of progeny of each cell grows until discrete mounds of cells are visible to the unassisted eye. These mounds of cells are termed <button class='glossary-text'>colonies</button>, and each colony may be considered a pure culture. Any colony may be subcultured by removing some of its cells and placing them in a fresh container of sterile growth medium. This allows for expansion of the pure culture to obtain large numbers of the microbe of interest for continued study.

In the isolation streak plate procedure, a small amount of mixed <button class='glossary-text'>inoculum</button> (i.e., the source material used for inoculation) is applied to the surface of plated agar. Only one small sector of the agar is inoculated, usually with an inoculating loop, in a zigzag pattern. Then a fresh, sterile inoculating loop is used to pull a small amount of inoculum from the original sector into an adjacent one, as shown in Figure 1. The process is repeated twice more until the last sector contains very thinly spread inoculum. The plate is then incubated.

pageData.disc: Figure 1: Four steps of the zigzag technique for creating an isolation streak plate.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Four steps of the zigzag technique for creating an isolation streak plate.

pageData.text: When growth appears, the first sector to be inoculated often has continuous thick growth, known as <button class='glossary-text'>confluent</button> growth, in which individual colonies cannot be discerned (lower half of Figure 2). Subsequently, inoculated sectors will have less dense growth, until the last sector or so has individual, isolated colonies (top half of Figure 2).

pageData.disc: Figure 2: Bacterial growth on an isolation streak plate. The bacteria is a film of continuous growth on the bottom third of the plate that thins out into distinct round colonies of growth toward the top of the plate.

pageData.text: In this investigation, you will do something very unusual for a microbiology experiment: you will combine two <button class='glossary-text'>pure cultures</button>. This is so you will have a mixture to separate that consists of only two known, easily identifiable microorganisms. Mastery of the <button class='glossary-text'>isolation streak plate</button> technique helps microbiologists obtain microbial mixtures from a wide variety of environmental sources containing a multitude of unknown microorganisms and use them to generate pure cultures for study.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, disinfect your worksurface and prepare your disposal jar. Then, prepare the bacterial cultures and the nutrient agar plate. To begin, pipet the M. luteus and S. marcescens into the sterile culture tube and mix. Then, inoculate the loop in the mixed culture and use it to inoculate one quarter of the nutrient agar plate with a zigzag motion. Next, turn the plate 90 degrees. Then, drag the same loop through the previous zigzag and inoculate the next quarter of the plate. Repeat this until all 4 quarters have been inoculated. Next, incubate the inoculated plate. After 48 hours of incubation, observe the plate growth every 24 hours.

In particular, each time you remove the cap from a tube, the cap should be held, not placed on the work surface. The open mouth of each glass culture tube should be flamed as soon as the cap is removed and immediately before the cap is replaced.

Culture RecommendationsYou will need relatively fresh broth cultures of Serratia marcesens and Micrococcus luteus for this investigation to be successful. Do not start Activity 1 until you have viable cultures of both organisms.If you have already carried out the Aseptic Technique and Use of Media investigation, you may have activated a lyophilized culture of use S. marcesens.A reactivated culture of either organism that will be no more than two weeks old at the time you start Activity 1 may be used as it is.If a culture has already been reactivated and is more than two weeks old, it will need to be transferred to a fresh tube of tryptic soy broth and allowed to grow.If a lyophilized culture has not been reactivated, you will need to reactivate it and allow time for growth before proceeding to Activity 1. The following steps will guide you in preparing your cultures. Read over them carefully before you begin.

pageData.text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm water. Dry your hands, and then put on your PPE.
Disinfect the work surface, culture tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with a 10% bleach solution.

If the media have been stored in the refrigerator, retrieve them from storage and allow them to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature. As a general rule, it is good practice to let media assume room temperature prior to use.

pageData.text: Prepare your disposal jar by filling it with 70% isopropyl alcohol. Used inoculating loops and/or pipettes will be placed in this jar.
Obtain the liquid paraffin candle from the equipment set. Light the candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from the open container of isopropyl alcohol.

If you will need to transfer an older, reactivated culture to fresh broth, follow Steps 79 for that organism. If you will need to reactivate a lyophilized culture, follow Steps 1015 for that organism. If both cultures are fresh (no more than two weeks old), proceed directly to Step 17.
Review the video:

typeBefore.subTitle: To Transfer an Older, Reactivated Broth Culture to Fresh Broth

pageData.text: Mix the contents of the culture by tapping the tube or rolling it between your palms.
Aseptically transfer a loop of broth to a fresh tube of tryptic soy broth.
Review the video:
Aseptically transfer 1 mL of tryptic soy broth from the tube that came with the lyophilized culture to the vial containing the culture pellet.
Allow the pellet to rehydrate for 30 seconds, then use the pipette to help break up and dissolve the pellet.
Aseptically transfer the contents of the culture vial to the tube of tryptic soy broth.
Extinguish the candle, and follow the Disposal and Cleanup guidelines at the end of this investigation.

Incubate the inoculated broth tube(s) upright in the rack with the cap(s) slightly loose. For convenience, both may be incubated at approximately 25 C (77 F). Allow between 2 and 4 days of incubation for signs of growth (turbidity and/or an increase in sediment) to appear.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Note: Both Micrococcus luteus and Staphylococcus epidermidis are non-motile and their growth will be along the bottom of the tube. You can gently swirl the tube to see if the growth at bottom of the tube moves. If you see a good swirl of growth at the bottom then your culture should be ready to proceed to the next step.The Escherichia coli and Serratia marcescens are both motile and their growth should be throughout the culture medium so they will appear turbid though they will also have more growth along the bottom of the tube. Wait until your culture is turbid before proceeding to Activity 2. Micrococcus luteus is fastidious and grows slowly at suboptimal conditions. If incubating at cooler temperatures, it may take five days or more for some strains to become significantly turbid.
Once growth is evident, prepare to work as described in Steps 15.
Obtain a tryptic soy agar plate.
Obtain all materials needed from the equipment set.

In Activity 1, you will mix bacteria from your previously prepared cultures of M. luteus and S. marcesens and streak the combined culture on a sterile agar plate using technique. You will then incubate your cultures and observe the differences in colonial growth for identification and isolation.
Mix the contents of each culture tube by tapping or rolling gently between your palms.

Note: It is important that all the cells are in suspension. If there is a mass of cells (sediment) at the bottom of the tube, it may be necessary to gently invert the tube to ensure the cells are in suspension. Once your cells are in suspension, your culture should appear turbid.
Using a sterile plastic pipette, transfer 10 drops of M. luteus into an empty sterile culture tube.
Using a different sterile plastic pipette, transfer one drop of S. marcesens into the sterile culture tube from Step 2.
Note: More M. luteus culture is used than S. marcesens because M. luteus tends to grow more slowly.
Mix the contents of the culture tube by tapping or rolling gently between your palms. This is your <button class='glossary-text'>mixed culture</button>.

Obtain a loop of broth from the mixed culture and inoculate about one-quarter of the surface of the agar in your plate in a zigzag pattern as shown in Figure 3. Please note that, for the sake of clarity, the lid of the Petri dish is not shown in Figures 37.

Note: Part of correct aseptic technique is avoiding excessive removal of the lid from a Petri dish. Open the lid just enough to insert and move the loop, and use the lid as a shield to keep dust off of the agar surface. Close the lid as soon as you are finished.

pageData.disc: Figure 3: Drawing of a hand holding an inoculating loop which is being used to streak the first sector, about a quarter of the surface, of the agar in a Petri dish.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Drawing of a hand holding an inoculating loop which is being used to streak the first sector, about a quarter of the surface, of the agar in a Petri dish.

pageData.text: Place your inoculating loop in the disposal jar. Take a new sterile loop, rotate the plate about 90, and pull some <button class='glossary-text'>inoculum</button> from the first sector of the agar into the adjacent sector, using a zigzag pattern, as shown in Figure 4.

Note: Only take inoculum directly from the mixed culture one time to streak the first sector. Subsequently, you will use a new sterile inoculating loop for each sector, without inserting any of the loops back into the mixed culture. The second streak should only pass through the first sector once or twice, not repeatedly, to achieve separation of the colonies.

pageData.disc: Figure 4: Drawing of a hand holding an inoculating loop which is being used to streak the second sector, about a quarter of the surface, of the agar in a Petri dish.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Drawing of a hand holding an inoculating loop which is being used to streak the second sector, about a quarter of the surface, of the agar in a Petri dish.

pageData.text: Place the inoculating loop in the disposal jar, rotate the plate, and use a new sterile loop to pull inoculum from the second sector into an adjacent one, as shown in Figure 5.

pageData.disc: Figure 5: Drawing of a hand holding an inoculating loop which is being used to streak the third sector, about a quarter of the surface, of the agar in a Petri dish.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Drawing of a hand holding an inoculating loop which is being used to streak the third sector, about a quarter of the surface, of the agar in a Petri dish.

pageData.text: Place the inoculating loop in the disposal jar, rotate the plate, and use a new sterile loop to pull inoculum from the third sector into the final one, as shown in Figure 6. Extra care should be taken in the fourth and final streak to ensure the loop does not touch or pass through the first sector; doing so will prevent the isolation of single colonies.

Invert the plate so it is lid-side down, and using the grease pencil or permanent marker, label the outside of the bottom of the plate with the names of the two organisms (M. luteus and S. marcesens) and the date of inoculation. Your plate is now ready for incubation.
Unless otherwise instructed, keep your M. luteus and S. marcesens cultures for later use. The mixed culture may be disinfected and discarded as described in the Disposal and Cleanup section.

pageData.disc: Figure 6: Drawing of a hand holding an inoculating loop which is being used to streak the fourth sector, about a quarter of the surface, of the agar in a Petri dish.
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Drawing of a hand holding an inoculating loop which is being used to streak the fourth sector, about a quarter of the surface, of the agar in a Petri dish.

pageData.text: Your streak plate may be incubated at approximately 25 C (77 F). After approximately 48 hours of incubation, examine your plate with the lid on. Do not remove the lid of the Petri dish during any observations, as doing so may result in contamination. Do not be alarmed if little or no growth is evident at 48 hours.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Prepare to photograph your plate. Avoid the use of the flash, which will simply be reflected off of the lid. Do not remove the lid of the Petri dish to take photos. You may need to experiment with lighting conditions and camera angles to get the best pictures in your work space.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Observe and photograph the plate again at approximately 72 and 96 hours.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Note: Micrococcus luteus is fastidious and grows slowly at suboptimal conditions. If incubating at cooler temperatures, it may take five days or more for some strains to show significant growth.

To dispose of used inoculating tools (loops, pipettes, etc.), let them soak in the disposal jar with isopropyl alcohol for at least 30 minutes. Then, while wearing PPE, pour the alcohol down the drain while the faucet is running and discard the materials wrapped in an opaque plastic bag in the garbage. Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol.
Keep your broth cultures of M. luteus and S. marcesens for later use unless other-wise directed by your instructor.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: To dispose of cultures that are no longer needed and the used culture vial and stopper, put on your PPE, ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a plastic container large enough to hold all the cultures with a 10% bleach solution. Hold each tube, vial, or plate submerged in the bleach solution, and then open. Allow the cultures to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Then, while wearing your PPE, pour the bleach down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach. Place the disinfected tubes and plates in an opaque plastic bag, and discard in the garbage.

data.title: Confluent
data.content: Describes microbial growth that is continuous and thick such that individual colonies cannot be discerned

data.title: Colony
data.content: A group of cells derived from the same mother cell

data.title: Inoculum
data.content: The microbes used to inoculate a medium

data.title: Isolation streak plate
data.content: A common microbiological technique used to isolate pure cultures from a mixed culture

data.title: Mixed culture
data.content: A sample of microbes that contains more than one bacteria, fungi, or other microbial species

data.title: Pure culture
data.content: A sample of genetically-identical microbes that is free of other species or strains
